remixlab.proscene
Interface MouseGrabber

All Known Implementing Classes:
InteractiveCameraFrame, InteractiveFrame
public interface MouseGrabber

Interface for objects that grab mouse focus in a Scene.

MouseGrabber are objects which react to the mouse cursor, usually when it hovers over them.

How does it work ?

All the created MouseGrabbers are grouped in a mouse grabber pool. The Scene parse this pool, calling all the MouseGrabbers' checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, Camera) methods that setGrabsMouse(boolean) if desired (method calls should actually be performed on concrete class instances such as InteractiveFrame).

When a MouseGrabber grabsMouse(), it becomes the Scene.mouseGrabber(). All the mouse events are then transmitted to it instead of being normally processed. This continues while grabsMouse() (updated using checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, Camera)) returns true.

If you want to (temporarily) disable a specific MouseGrabbers, you can remove it from this pool using removeFromMouseGrabberPool().

Field Detail

MouseGrabberPool

static final java.util.List<MouseGrabber> MouseGrabberPool
Method Detail

getMouseGrabberPool

java.util.List<MouseGrabber> getMouseGrabberPool()
Returns a list containing references to all the active MouseGrabbers.

Used by the Scene to parse all the MouseGrabbers and to check if any of them grabsMouse() checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, Camera).

You should not have to directly use this list. Use removeFromMouseGrabberPool() and addInMouseGrabberPool() to modify this list.

See Also:
getMouseGrabberPool()

checkIfGrabsMouse

void checkIfGrabsMouse(int x,
                       int y,
                       Camera camera)
Called by the Scene before they test if the MouseGrabber grabsMouse(). Should setGrabsMouse(boolean) according to the mouse position.

This is the core method of the MouseGrabber. Its goal is to update the grabsMouse() flag according to the mouse and MouseGrabber current positions, using setGrabsMouse(boolean).

grabsMouse() is usually set to true when the mouse cursor is close enough to the MouseGrabber position. It should also be set to false when the mouse cursor leaves this region in order to release the mouse focus.

x and y are the mouse cursor coordinates ((0,0) corresponds to the upper left corner).

A typical implementation will look like:

// (posX,posY) is the position of the MouseGrabber on screen.
// Here, distance to mouse must be less than 10 pixels to activate the MouseGrabber.
setGrabsMouse( PApplet.sqrt((x-posX)*(x-posX) + (y-posY)*(y-posY)) < 10);

If the MouseGrabber position is defined in 3D, use the camera parameter, corresponding to the calling Scene Camera. Project on screen and then compare the projected coordinates:

PVector proj = new PVector (camera.projectedCoordinatesOf(myMouseGrabber.frame().position());
setGrabsMouse((PApplet.abs(x-proj.x) < 5) && (PApplet.(y-proj.y) < 2)); // Rectangular region

mousePressEvent

void mousePressEvent(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event,
                     Camera camera)
Callback method called when the MouseGrabber grabsMouse() and a mouse button is pressed.

The MouseGrabber will typically start an action or change its state when a mouse button is pressed. mouseMoveEvent(MouseEvent, Camera) (called at each mouse displacement) will then update the MouseGrabber accordingly and mouseReleaseEvent(MouseEvent, Camera) (called when the mouse button is released) will terminate this action.

mouseMoveEvent

void mouseMoveEvent(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event,
                    Camera camera)
Callback method called when the MouseGrabber grabsMouse() and the mouse is moved while a button is pressed.

This method will typically update the state of the MouseGrabber from the mouse displacement. See the mousePressEvent(MouseEvent, Camera) documentation for details.

                       Camera camera)
